Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Sir2 proteins, also known as sirtuins, comprise an ancient family of NAD+-dependent enzymes found in all organisms, where they play a central role in diverse biological processes including transcriptional silencing, suppression of rDNA recombination, regulation of the p53 tumor suppressor, fat mobilization, neuronal regeneration, and aging. Most sirtuins deacetylate lysine residues in an NAD+-dependent reaction that releases the deacetylated peptide, nicotinamide, and O-acetyl ADP ribose. The unusual chemistry catalyzed by sirtuins allows some of these enzymes to catalyze a second reaction, ADP ribosylation, in which NAD+ is cleaved and the ADP ribose product is attached to target side chains. In the past funding period, significant progress was made towards elucidating the structure-based mechanism of NAD+-dependent deacetylation. In addition, the first direct evidence for ADP ribosylation by a sirtuin was obtained and the modified side chains identified. The present proposal builds upon this work, applying approaches using x-ray crystallography, biochemistry, and computational biology to understand the underlying mechanism of the ADP ribosyltransferase activity of sirtuins. Structures of complexes with substrates and trapped reaction intermediates will be determined using x-ray crystallography in order to uncover the mechanism by which sirtuins ADP ribosylate acetylated and unacetylated substrates. Solution studies and quantum mechanical calculations on the new structures will complement these structural studies and will shed further light on the enzymatic mechanism. In a second area of inquiry, structural and biochemical studies will be carried out on the complex formed by the yeast Sir2 protein with Net1, which is responsible for rDNA silencing and suppression of rDNA recombination. These studies will shed light on how Net1 recruits Sir2 to the nucleolus and establishes a chromatin-bound complex that silences transcription and suppresses recombination. In addition to elucidating how Sir2 interacts with partner proteins, these studies will also contribute to an understanding of why the enzymatic activity of Sir2 is altered when it becomes part of a complex.

BROADER IMPACT OF THE PROPOSED ACTIVITY: The proposed experiments will be carried out exclusively by graduate students and will provide excellent training in using an integrated approach that applies the tools of x-ray crystallography and solution biochemistry to important biological problems. The principal investigator's ongoing work in structural biology of sirtuins has provided an opportunity to reach out to and encourage women and underrepresented groups to pursue a career in science. The principal investigator participates in the "Women Serious About Science" club at a city high school with a largely minority student body. She has also devised and taught a curriculum for "Crystal Day" as part of a new summer program for inner-city 5th graders that is taught annually.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sirtuins are a class of enzymes found in all organisms that regulate a broad range of biological processes including gene expression, metabolism, aging, inflammation and cell death. The overarching goal of our research is to uncover the mechanisms by which sirtuins regulate such a diverse array of processes as well as how those functions have been conserved through evolution. Sirtuins were originally shown to remove acetyl groups from lysine side chains in substrate proteins, via a reaction that utilized the high-energy molecule, NAD+ as a cofactor. However, recent studies have shown that sirtuins can also remove other types of acyl modifications from lysines, and that these activities also underlie the biological roles of sirtuin enzymes. In the past funding period, our studies focused on determining how sirtuins locate their correct targets. In particular, we investigated how sirtuins target particular substrate lysine residues and how different sirtuins discriminate among different types of acyl modifications. We developed a technique that enables one to compare the lysine specificity of different sirtuins and discovered that the yeast sirtuin, Sir2, preferentially targets a specific residue, Lysine 79, within histone H3, one of the proteins that packages genomic DNA. Sir2 deacetylates this residue, thereby regulating gene silencing. In parallel, we investigated whether two previously studied sirtuins that were thought to be deacetylases could also remove other types of acyl modifications. We found that the archaeal sirtuin, Sir2Af1, preferentially removes negatively charged succinyl groups whereas Sir2Af2 preferentially removes hydrophobic fatty acyl chains. Structural studies of both sirtuins bound to their cognate substrates revealed features within each enzyme active site that confer specificity for each class of acyl modification. These findings point to both structural and biochemical plasticity in sirtuin active sites and provide further evidence that sirtuins from all three domains of life catalyze noncanonical deacylation.

 

The studies described here provided training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, who carried out these studies. The PI is also actively involved in outreach to underrepresented minority students in Baltimore City middle school and high school as well as at the undergraduate level. The laboratory participates in the annual Johns Hopkins Community Science day, Fun with Science Camp, and Biophysics for Baltimore Teens. These programs provide opportunities for students to learn about the excitement of science and the possibilities for future science careers.
